displayed_text: Family Member: Hi. Nice to meet you. Doctor: So you did your whole drive downtown here, all of that? Patient: Yes. I did. Doctor: How have you been feeling overall? Patient: I’m fine. Yeah. Did this once. (Laughs) Doctor: I know. Yeah. But, I still feel hurt that it didn’t- Patient: I know. I know. Doctor: You feel it too, I’m sure. Patient: You get the PSA yet? Doctor: Not yet. But last time it was going down. Patient: It was one, one, yeah. Doctor: So it went from one point one. Yeah. Patient: How long does it take to see the CAT scan?

Patient: None of that. Doctor: And how just overall energy level since we stopped the study have you had? Noticed worsening, better, same? Patient: Well, uh, I could say, I don’t have as much energy as I had when I was on testosterone. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Right? So that, that has diminished. Uh, uh, let’s see, I, I’m just trying to think through the process because I’m still- Doctor: I mean, you’re still up? You’re still kind of doing the things you want to do? You’re not like-? Patient: Right. Right. Right. Right. Right. Yeah. Because we was on vacation for twelve days. So that, that threw off everything with me. Doctor: Since I saw you last? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Where’d you guys go? Patient: South Africa. Doctor: Oh, that’s right. How was that? Patient: Oh, mind blowing.

Patient: But, okay, okay. Doctor: You’ll still do… Patient: That’s my only concern because because whoever called to schedule it said R__ you can do it before the holiday or do it afterward. Doctor: Yeah… Patient: We’ve got family coming and stuff like that too so… Doctor: So I think you should just do it after you know you finish radiation June eighth so that’s we’re covered and everything is great, your counts are fine. So you know you’re anemic is still at, your hemoglobin is still at eight point nine. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which is great. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Post radiation… Patient: So it came up then and just… Doctor: Yeah you’re fine.

Patient: Very good. Okay. Sounds good. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: So what would the, uh, CAT scan show today? Just soft tissue? Patient: She doesn’t know yet. Family Member: maybe it’ll show Doctor: Well, I think maybe his disease was mainly in the lymph nodes. So that is what we will be following and the spine is visible on the CAT scan, too. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So we might as well get an impression of what the bones, what’s going on in the lower back, and all of that, as well as mainly the lymph nodes is what I want to keep an eye on. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But I think maybe the Xofigo is still doing its stuff. Patient: Um hum. Yeah. Your husband did a good job. Doctor: As long as everything is in remission. Yeah. (Laughter) Doctor: On and off, I guess I’ll compliment him, then. (Laughter)

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.::: strongly disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.::: strongly disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind::: strongly disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Some other race: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Some other race

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yet? Patient: I just got it just now. Doctor: You did get it okay good. Patient: A couple days ago. Doctor: Yeah because the flu has been bad this year so. Healthcare Professional 1: So he’ll be due for the Lupron his next visit correct? Doctor: Yep Healthcare Professional 1: Okay. Doctor: Well I mean you might as well get it authorized. Healthcare Professional 1: Right. Doctor: If he’s one day here or there (mumbling)

Family Member: For prostate? Doctor: So what we’re doing – yes, yeah, within prostate cancer. So what we’re doing now is what we’re proposing is that we screen your uh blood, it’s a blood test, that to look for any of those eight genes or mutations that if your cancer has those then I would recommend going on this particular study which gives you these medications which are pills that you would take and we’d monitor you to see if it’s likely to be helpful. Family Member: Is it a type of chemo? Doctor: It is not. It is something called parp… so more like what we call targeted therapy. Okay but it’s different from the immune therapy that you were having. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And I think it has a pretty good shot at working like I said if you had one of those mutations. Patient: Okay as far as working what do you mean by that? I mean is it something… Doctor: Working against – shrinking the cancer and helping – working against the… Family Member: Targeting drugs and genes (doc and fam talking at the same time.) Doctor: Targeting exactly the cancer that you have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now there is another option, I know you’re completely reluctant to go on chemotherapy. You know there is obviously that would be the standard treatment that you know we would – if we advise that and if you decide you want that you could easily get it in lots and closer to home.

Patient: Um did you have to do radiation on them? Doctor: In some of those patients yes. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Right and uh um. Patient: Did you come high? Doctor: Not high immediately, but uh… Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: …it continues to rise. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And in those patients we may offer radiation therapy, radiation therapy with hormonal therapy. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: But we’ll wait and see what happens in your case.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: For this, I’ve got a, I think for this, the trial, they were able to use the experience with Germany to say you probably could start about here. You don’t have to start way down here. And I don’t think it’s the same exactly like a regular drug phase one. So I think they’re kind of already in a in a sort of Goldilocks spot. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So that’s the only difference between you know in Germany everybody gets, they individualize it based on what they looked at is how much of the scan is your cancer taking off. They try, they, they describe what they said that if you took up that much material, you need to get this much. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So they give, they dose it based on how much of an exposure. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, I think, again, what’s the best way to go? I mean the groups in Germany have way more experience doing this. Family Member: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Uh but you know it’s more complicated because you’ve got to go to Germany and all that, all those, there’s, there’s a layer to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Although you know saying that, you still would have to go away from home.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you know the clinical trials and also the clinical experience do suggest that when you combine standard hormone therapy with chemotherapy or standard hormone therapy with newer type of hormone therapy called (novel) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. But but again, I don’t want you to go into that thinking that it’s going to increase the chance of a cure. The cure rate is still you know pretty close to zero percent and that it increases the length of time that that systemic therapy works. Patient: Okay. And see, that that that’s my concern at this point. Um you know um you think in terms of the reason I keep pushing hormonal so far back is because I know that’s a proven method - Doctor: Yeah. It is - Patient: - or a proven therapy that will slow the progression. So I know that. So thinking in terms of that uh if there was something else that was being done before we actually hit that, that’s almost like saying, “This is my little (laughs) Family Member: Right, right. Patient: You know to hold, you know while I try other things. Of course I have to go relying on your experience. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Uh hum. Patient: And that’s your level of expertise what you’re doing. You’re the oncologist. You know so I’m going to have to weigh… Doctor: Yeah. Sure.

Patient: Yes. So I just want to be patient. Doctor: Okay, and it may, and it very well may, because it’s just, uh, let’s see, it was done, you had the operation on-. Patient: Uh, on the fourteenth of September. Doctor: September? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So you’re not quite a year? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So alright well let’s, let’s continue with the same course. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And see what happens, alright? Patient: Um hum. I’ve been working and so, so you know, I’ve been keeping busy without that. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Alright. Very good.

Patient: Right. I got it. Doctor: What they are allowed to do there is use the material as long as they don’t try to sell it outside their hospital or use it outside the hospital, they’re allowed to do it. And the material they’re using is kind of an off-the-shelf thing where they could buy it, make it on site. Uh in the U.S. what’s gotten problematic is I think we’re on the third company now that’s tried to develop this. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: The first two companies kind of went under. It’s a little bit complicated with the drug involved because it’s radioactive. You’ve got to have a whole infrastructure. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: To make sure the radiation is here on Tuesday when you’re here. It’s not like you just go over to the pharmacy and grab it because there’s all that stuff. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I think it’s going to come pretty quickly. So the company that our group because our group invented it. It’s a company in France, that is a very experienced company developing new uh radioactive things. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That company just got bought by N___ Patient: Oh. Doctor: for five billion dollars. So there’s now a kind of uh a big shift. So I think it’s going to happen.

Patient: Good morning, Dr. B___ Good seeing you. Doctor: Nice seeing you, too. Yes, ah. You don’t have to come in, right? Healthcare Professional: No. I don’t. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Very good. (Door closes) Patient: Okay. Doctor: It hasn’t changed, and, uh, that’s a good thing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And how’s the water passing? Patient: All them things good. Doctor: You’re not wearing a pad? Patient: No. Doctor: No leakage?

Patient: Both sides, and - Doctor: All right. Patient: Yeah. Healthcare Professional: Still having constipation issues? Come and go? Patient: Of course (chuckles) Doctor: Okay, so with the chemo now, the things to keep track of any kind of fevers, infections, anything I need to know right away. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Now what’s the best way to - Doctor: Get in touch with me? So one-eight hundred_____. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: And you ask them to page me. Family Member: All right.

Patient: Yeah, it’s Rite Aid F___. Doctor: Two r’s or one r in F___? Patient: Two. No, it’s just one. Doctor: And do you know the zip for F___? Patient: No. Family Member: Umm, two oh five oh, maybe? (pause) Doctor: F___ five - one five two zero R____. Patient: That’s the one. R____ Doctor: You’ll take that for thirty days, and that will be sent there electronically, so you would be able to pick it up later today. Patient: Okay. Eh, any particular time of day? I’m sure it will come with, just as long as it is around the same time every day. Healthcare Professional: It just says “take it approximately, about the same time each day.” And you can take it with or without food. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that will just cause, uh, a little bit of soft stool.

Patient: That’s it. Doctor: No other medicines for pain, anything else for the allergies – Patient: No. Doctor: Or vitamins? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. And when you were in the hospital, did they put any tubes or anything in, anything of that you still have. Patient: Yes, they put catheter in and uh they gave me I.V. at the beginning and made sure the catheter was out. Doctor: The catheter is out now? Patient: Now it’s not; See that is the problem. Uh catheter was not out when it was supposed to be scheduled; the catheter but two days before it was supposed to be taken out I Doctor: Even with the catheter in? Patient: Well, the catheter was blocked. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So I went again back to the emergency hospital and they made a mistake; they pulled it out. I still couldn’t pee. And I had peeing, but very little at the time. So they said it’s not doing it properly, so they put catheter back in. And they told me they shouldn’t have taken out. So the urologist told me; they should have flushed it and anyway, so.
